title: 107_hr2999
content: The "First Things First Act" is the short title of this legislation, with the purpose outlined in Section 2. The "First Things First Act" aims to delay certain amendments to the Internal Revenue Code until critical national priorities are achieved, including aid for 9/11 victims, securing Social Security and Medicare funds, providing prescription drug benefits to Medicare beneficiaries, funding school modernization, and reducing worst-case housing needs for US citizens since 2001. SEC. 3. MODIFICATION OF THE HIGHEST MARGINAL INCOME TAX RATES. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding reductions in rates after June 30, 2001. The highest marginal income tax rates were modified for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. The corresponding percentages for different taxable years were adjusted, with the highest rate being 39.6% for years starting in 2001 and beyond. The repeal of certain sections of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 eliminates the phaseout of overall limitation on itemized deductions, termination of personal exemptions, estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes, and step-up in basis at death. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be applied as if these sections had never been enacted. SEC. 6 increases the estate tax deduction for family-owned business interest from $675,000 to $4,000,000. The effective date for this amendment is for estates of decedents dying after the enactment of the Act. The "National Priorities Assessment Task Force" is established in the legislative branch to determine Congress's achievements in providing aid after the 9/11 attacks, securing Social Security and Medicare funds, offering prescription drug benefits to Medicare beneficiaries, funding school modernization, and reducing housing needs for US citizens since 2001. The "National Priorities Assessment Task Force" is composed of 16 members from various House and Senate committees to address the housing needs of United States citizens. The National Priorities Assessment Task Force, consisting of members from Senate committees, will submit a final report to Congress within 30 days of making determinations, detailing findings and conclusions. The Task Force will transmit a final report to Congress after making determinations. Interim reports may also be submitted. Members serve without pay, 9 members constitute a quorum, and the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are elected by members. The Task Force may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. The Task Force may obtain official data from US departments or agencies as needed. No funds can be provided to the Task Force, but committee funds can be used by Task Force members who are also committee members. The Task Force will terminate 30 days after its work is completed. The Task Force will terminate 30 days after transmitting its final report under subsection (d).
